awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Infusing Inquiry-Based Green Chemistry into Undergraduate Laboratory Courses via Silver Recycling in a Closed Loop, Multi-course Process
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Tuskegee University seeks to improve the undergraduate chemistry experience through guided inquiry pedagogical methods, addition of new instrumentation and real-world application of green chemistry. The proposed program includes linking chemistry concepts and green chemical methods to hands-on research experiences that will stimulate students' awareness and the pursuit of scientific careers. Students will be exposed to overarching themes of green chemistry, recycling, and sustainability, as well as their impact on the world.  Since Chemistry is a service department for majors in four colleges at Tuskegee University, the proposed activities' emphasis on proper waste disposal, environmental impacts, and green chemistry principles will not only have a broad institutional impact, but will have a major impact on preparing students for a global STEM workforce.

The overall goal of the program is to improve Tuskegee University's chemistry laboratory curriculum and the environment through three initiatives: 1) professional development activities for teaching with a guided inquiry-based model; 2) inclusion of Green Chemistry principles throughout the chemistry laboratory curriculum; and 3) increased student hands-on access to instrumentation. The goals will be accomplished through the development of several Guided Inquiry experiments that begin from the waste stream of the general chemistry laboratory. Silver salt waste from general chemistry laboratory will be collected and purified by analytical chemistry laboratory students.  The purified silver salts will be reused in general chemistry and used as catalysts in organic chemistry laboratory synthesis.  Students in nanotechnology will use the recycled silver to synthesize silver nanoparticles and investigate their biological activities.  These silver nanoparticles will be utilized in the biochemistry laboratories to demonstrate their antimicrobial properties.  Thus, the project will be a closed loop process that involves various levels of the institution's chemistry laboratories.  Two significant benefits of the proposed activity include diversification of the experiment portfolio and the reduction of laboratory waste.

por.por_cntn:
Green chemistry practices and sustainability affect how science is performed, from fundamental studies to commercial processes. When integrated as early as freshman year of college, these practices may help decrease the cost and reduce the negative environmental impact of chemical consumables. Additionally, it may broadly enhance societies' view of chemistry beyond its role as an enabler of technology to a facilitator of safe and reliable products that positively influence the environment.

The inclusion of green and sustainable chemistry approaches throughout the existing chemistry curriculum has enhanced the chemistry department's offering of less hazardous experiments and research skills. The undergraduate and graduate students have been exposed to the overarching theme of green chemistry, recycling, and its impact on our world. Moreover, students involved in this work were part of a multi-step closed-loop process that they ultimately followed semester-by-semester, ending in a newly found appreciation for sustainable practices.

The redesign of the laboratory experiments has strengthened research training and allowed new active-learning methodologies to be implemented within the chemistry curriculum at Tuskegee University. Our revamped courses have increased students' hands-on access to instrumentation and integrated their learning through sustainable chemistry research experiences.

Furthermore, the students have gained hands-on training on spectroscopic, synthetic, and processing techniques while acquiring independent thinking skills aided by Guided Inquiry methodologies. In addition, the graduate students mentored their undergraduate peers, prepared lab materials, wrote procedures, and facilitated group discussions. Likewise, faculty professional development activities on teaching an inquiry-based model of sustainable chemistry have enhanced our department by offering senior seminar classes as a capstone green chemistry experience for chemistry majors. As a result, many students have co-authored several posters and abstracts and presented their works at regional and national conferences. 

The diversification of our experiment portfolio and the reduction of our laboratory waste has promoted sustainable chemistry awareness at Tuskegee University to make the connections from chemistry concepts to the real world we live in through the development of effective problem solvers and analytical thinkers for today's visual and technology-driven world.
